ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Reading through a set of papers on the most recent developments in chemical biology within the past year has taught me how to critically evaluate the literature. Along the way I've picked up new or recent techniques used in the field, and the two presentations we each had to give (one individually and one as a group) was good practice. Many of the papers involved a drug design component that was extremely instructive and useful for me.
Better understanding of chemical biology and critical thinking skills for analyzing published research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The paper-a-week format (and quiz every class written by the student presenting the paper) was effective. Sometimes the quiz may have been a little harder or too focused on the details, but overall they were relatively fair. Some of the papers could have benefitted from being paired with other companion papers to help contextualize the focus and provide more details to help read the "main" paper.
Strengths: analysis of papers, student presentations Weaknesses: student written quizzes focused too much on small details

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The course is an excellent survey of recent developments in chemical biology via critical reading of papers in the field (all papers from the past year). In each class we critically evaluated the results and data of each paper and had a thorough discussion. For each paper there is a quiz in class, written by the student presenting that paper, and each student presents a paper at least once. There were two exams, one on the first half of the semester's papers, and the second on the second half of papers. Many of the questions were based on ones submitted by the student presenters, with some questions written by Professor Schepartz herself.
